isis.stitle: VT-365 Diesel Engine Diagnostics (2002) - PERFORMANCE DIAGNOSTICS - Test Procedures - Fuel Pressure (Full load)

svcproc.title: Fuel Pressure (Full load)
svcproc.para: To determine if the fuel system supplies the engine with the correct fuel quantity and pressure at full load conditions

warning.para: To avoid serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the foreword of this manual. Follow all warnings, cautions, and notes.

note.para: Do this test at full load along with Test 14 (Boost Pressure) and 16 (Injection Control Pressure).

step1.para: See Appendix A in this manual for specifications, and record on Performance Diagnostics form.
Remove pipe plug from fuel filter housing (lower rear left).

warning.para: To prevent serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:

When routing test line, do not crimp the line, run the line too close to moving parts, or let the line touch hot engine surfaces. Secure the gauge bar and test line in the cab so as not to obstruct the operator.

step1.para: Route test line from engine compartment to cab.
Connect a line from the fuel/oil pressure test coupler to the 0-160 psi gauge on gauge bar, then connect to test fitting.
Drive vehicle and make sure engine operating temperature reaches 70°C (158°F).
Find a long, open stretch of road.
Select a suitable gear, press accelerator pedal fully to the floor, and accelerate to rated speed at 100% load.
Record gauge reading on diagnostics form.

item.para: If fuel pressure is low replace fuel filter, clean strainer, and retest.
If fuel pressure is still low, do Test 4 (Fuel Inlet Restriction) at full load, rated speed.

warning.para: To prevent serious personal injury, possible death, or damage to the engine or vehicle - comply with the following:

When routing test line , do not crimp the line, run the line too close to moving parts, or let the line touch hot engine surfaces. Secure the gauge bar and test line in the cab so as not to obstruct the operator.

item.para: Dirt or jelled fuel in the fuel filter will cause high restriction and low fuel pressure.
A kinked or bent fuel supply line or a blocked pickup tube can cause high restriction and low fuel pressure.
A loose fuel line on the suction side of the fuel system can ingest air into the system and cause low fuel pressure.
Internal fuel pump damage or damage to the drive gear
